claim: If you watch a pot of water on the stove, it will boil.

supporting.text: Water boils when it reaches its boiling point temperature of 100°C (212°F) at standard atmospheric pressure.

attacks.text: Water boils when it reaches its boiling point temperature of 100°C (212°F) at standard atmospheric pressure.
Watching the pot does not influence the boiling point of water; it will boil regardless of observation.
Observation can indirectly affect boiling time by altering heat application (e.g., adjusting the stove).
Minor adjustments from observation are negligible compared to the inherent boiling process.

supporting.text: Applying heat to a pot of water on a stove increases the water's temperature until it reaches the boiling point.

attacks.text: Applying heat to a pot of water on a stove increases the water's temperature until it reaches the boiling point.
If the stove is not turned on or lacks sufficient heat output, the water will not boil regardless of observation.
Standard stoves in normal conditions are designed to provide sufficient heat to boil water when turned on.
At high altitudes, water boils at a lower temperature, which may not be sufficient for cooking purposes despite technically reaching boiling point.
Most populated areas are not at sufficiently high altitudes to significantly affect cooking times or boiling behavior.
If the pot is uncovered, significant heat loss may occur, delaying or preventing boiling even with the stove on.
Standard cooking practices typically involve covering the pot to retain heat, making this scenario uncommon.

supporting.text: Watching the pot does not influence the boiling process; boiling depends on heat transfer and temperature.

attacks.text: Watching the pot does not influence the boiling process; boiling depends on heat transfer and temperature.
Human observation can indirectly affect boiling by adjusting heat settings or noticing anomalies (e.g., lid placement).
Such adjustments are external to the claim's core premise, which assumes passive observation without intervention.
Quantum mechanics suggests observation may influence physical systems at microscopic scales (observer effect).
The observer effect is negligible at macroscopic scales like boiling water, making this irrelevant to the claim.

supporting.text: If the stove is turned off or insufficient heat is applied, the water will not boil regardless of being watched.

attacks.text: If the stove is turned off or insufficient heat is applied, the water will not boil regardless of being watched.
The claim assumes the stove is on and sufficient heat is applied, making A4 irrelevant to the original statement.
Even if the stove is on, watching the pot does not influence the boiling process, so the claim is misleading.
The act of watching ensures the stove remains on and heat is maintained, indirectly supporting the claim.
